content.intro:
At the top of the list of most-liveable cities, Nantes combines a rich history with contemporary creativity in ways that never cease to surprise.

Once the largest port in France, the former 'Venice of the West' has managed over the years to become a city for travellers, for history, and for multifaceted ferment. With a vibrant university centre, it is also an arena for cultural expression open to the imagination, shining as well with innovative architectural projects that offer a new reading of urban space. It is at the centre of cultural friction and an island of creation, a true incubator of innovation and trade that now bubbles where the former shipyards once plied their trade along the harbour.

For the past 15 years, the ancient city of the Dukes of Brittany has been following a real change: today it is the city of 'the Elephant' and other extraordinary machines created for the delight of tourists who come to experience these monumental mechanical structures in motion. In the centre of the city, the newly restored Pommeraye Passage, the splendid Cours Cambronne, the Natural History Museum, the Graslin Theatre and the legendary brasserie La Cigale are opportunities to feast on past treasures, and to understand the wealth of this great metropolis.

Leave your car at the parking lot, because the city can easily be visited on foot, thanks to the tram network that runs from the botanical gardens to the Place Graslin, through the old town past the Cathedral of St Peter and St Paul, the Castle of the Dukes, and small pedestrian streets, without forgetting its run along the Quay of Versailles, where one can see the beginnings of the Erdre River next to the prefecture.

Something else not to be missed is the small port of Trentemoult with its fishermen's houses sporting colourful facades. The Navibus that crosses the Loire gives the journey a holiday feel. The writer Julien Gracq described Nantes as the 'bustling city... full of dreams' in his book The Shape of a City. Today, more than ever, Nantes, a creative, sparkling, and attractive place, is making those dreams come true.

content.title: Poetic and imaginary journey at the Jardin des plantes

introduction.small: A giant bench, animal-shaped sculpted plants, an unusual family playground… In Nantes, the Jardin des plantes is way more than a simple tribute to horticulture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Poetic and imaginary journey at the Jardin des plantes

paragraphs.text:
Listed as a garden of “remarkable interest”, the Jardin des plantes (Botanical garden) attracts no less than two million visitors each year, and it has remained a must in the city since it opened. For more than 150 years, plant collections have grown and the place has become a scientific study as well as a leisure park. Locals come to relax amid the seven hectares of greenery, lulled by the sound of waterfalls. Works of art are scattered around, like Wallace fountains, sculptor Camille Alaphilippe's Le Premier Miroir, Jules Verne's statue or Les Cerfs au repos.

Curious passersby will enter the 800 sqm of greenhouses and observe plants from around the world. Do not miss the ones that grow under dry climate, especially the many cactus species! However, this English garden is first and foremost dedicated to families and overgrown adults. Claude Ponti, famous author of children books, breathed in poetic imagination through twisted benches – including one that is 4-metre high! – or animal-shaped sculpted plants, as well as an Alice in Wonderland-style playground, where kids run amok through giants flower pots.

Jardin des plantes
Rue Stanislas Baudry
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 41 90 00

https://jardins.nantes.fr/En/Garden/Visit/Jardin-des-plantes-Visit.asp

content.title: When Maisons du Monde becomes a hotel

introduction.small: The famous brand of home decoration and furniture applies its experience to hospitality with a hotel located in the historic centre of Nantes, only a few miles from its headquarters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: When Maisons du Monde becomes a hotel

paragraphs.text:
From the lobby onward and just like its stores, Maisons du Monde's very first hotel is stylish, full of plants and inspired by the world over. Only missing is the check-in counter, since you will find a simple and modern tablet instead. Increasing the feeling of travelling around, the hotel offers 47 rooms decorated in 5 different styles. Here, everything has been devised as a home away from home. The concept is to give clients an experience that differs from classic hospitality fashions. Depending on your mood, choose the “ExploChic” style, adapted to adventure seekers or the “Jagger” for adepts of glamour and rock'n roll. The “Green Grey” is dedicated to nature's fauna and flora, the “Classique Chic” displays a more subdued atmosphere and the “Exochic” mixes styles with a plant wall and industrial feel. Families will appreciate the connected bedrooms – simply ask for them.

True to the brand philosophy set up by its headquarters based in Vertou (in the suburb of Nantes), this Maisons du Monde Hôtel & Suites pays particular attention to ecological issues: the entire furniture has thus been awarded the protection and sustainable forest management label.

Maisons du monde Hôtel & Suites
2 bis rue Santeuil
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 73 46 68

https://www.maisonsdumondehotel.com/en/

Rooms: from 99 EUR

content.title: LuluRouget, starred and affordable

introduction.small: One of the very best restaurants in town, run by chef Ludovic Pouzelgues. It offers market-based cuisine to the utmost.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LuluRouget, starred and affordable

paragraphs.text:
After making a name for itself in the city centre, LuluRouget moved a stone's throw from the famous machines of the Île de Nantes, looking to renew itself. The enterprise was met with success since the restaurant was awarded its first Michelin star! But the glory has not modified the spirit not the drive of chef Ludovic Pouzelgues. Born in Nantes, he undertook to modernize market-based cuisine in a setting that would be closer to a bistro restaurant.

LuluRouget switches white tablecloths and silverware for a raw and industrial yet welcoming style, bringing together stone, wood and concrete, for a result as cosy as it is contemporary. With affordable pricing, especially for a starred restaurant, it is tempting to indulge in the “Eyes Shut” 4, 5 or 6-course menus that all depend on the current culinary inspirations of their maker. The only standard is called Petit Lulu (a nod to the Nantes biscuit), with parmesan and marrow or green peas and mint appetizers, according to the season. Faithful to the teachings of his mentor Michel Troisgros, Ludovic Pouzelgues adds a slight pinch of sourness to his dishes that sublimates all flavours. As for what comes next, you can have blind faith in the chef's prowess…

LuluRouget
Zéro Newton
4 place Albert Camus
44200 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 47 47 98

https://www.lulurouget.fr

Lunch menu from 32 EUR, dinner menu from 62 EUR

content.title: Meals on Spanish time at Entre Amigos

introduction.small: In the heart of Nantes' city centre, Entre Amigos is a Spanish-style bodega where you can enjoy tapas and other typically Iberian dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meals on Spanish time at Entre Amigos

paragraphs.text:
Entre Amigos stands out in the heart of the Tour de Bretagne neighbourhood. This small restaurant follows on the Spanish bar tradition, offering an inviting space where all generations can meet and share. Madrid native Gema Gonzalez therefore tries to integrate the concept in local Nantes culture, using tapas and typical dishes in her "my village" section of the menu, among other Spanish recipes dear to the owner's heart.
The inside is pared-down and modern, with yellow mustard and peacock blue chairs, as well as wicker lampshades that push it away from bodega clichés. Only a few Andalusian plates have been hung on the walls, and the friendly and inviting atmosphere obviously calls the Iberian Peninsula to mind. Chef Jesus, Spanish too, cooks series of tapas, tortillas and patatas bravas, as well as croquetas de jamón (ham) and pollo (chicken), not mentioning the famous meat and fish paellas. Ideal for a moment with your… amigos!

Entre Amigos
10, rue des Trois Croissants
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 20 17 67

www.entre-amigos.fr/en/

Menu: around 21 EUR

content.title: Les Domaines Qui Montent, for the love of terroir

introduction.small: In the heart of the City of Dukes, behind the doors of Les Domaines Qui Montent, is a wine cellar, a gourmet shop and a table d'hôte.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Domaines Qui Montent, for the love of terroir

paragraphs.text:
As you walk in the door of this quality shop from a group founded in 1989, hundreds of bottles of wine and regional products envelop you with their ineffable aromas-the Pays de la Loire in their purest form. Les Domaines qui Montent is part of a marketing approach for local businesses and, as such, is involved in the promotion of small farms and wineries.

To let you discover the wines and products of the region, Les Domaines Qui Montent has created a new concept for a gourmet shop-tables d'hôtes. Come enjoy a friendly moment around a delicious meal. On your plate you will taste a dish cooked by one of its artisans, pork cheeks in tarragon, turkey oyster in Meaux mustard or pork ribs in spices for instance. You can choose your wine, simply walk into the cellar or let yourself be guided by the sommelier. All bottles are at the same price whether you drink it on the spot or take it home! Les Domaines Qui Montent has other pleasant surprises in reserve: tasting evenings, personalised gift boxes, privatisation of the cellar, and organisation of a buffet... As you wish!

Les Domaines Qui Montent
10 rue des Hauts Pavés
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 53 78 46 17

https://www.lesdomainesquimontent.com/

Menu: around 22 EUR

content.title: Charm and delights on the terrace of Le Bouchon

introduction.small: Le Bouchon hides its culinary marvels behind a 15th century half-timbered facade. Real love at first sight for Nantes residents. We invite you to come in.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Charm and delights on the terrace of Le Bouchon

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of town, this restaurant has a small shaded terrace that is divine in the heat of summer. Servers welcome you with forthright smiles and lead you to a table in the stone-paved courtyard or in the intimate wood-panelled interior. With a bit of greenery and peace in the heart of Nantes, the place is particularly appreciated, and it is important to reserve in advance.

With discrete originality, the cuisine of the restaurant lights up seasonal products with a regularly updated menu: zucchini cappuccino, rack of lamb with herbs, sea bream tartare in mango and lime, grilled vegetables millefeuille and parmesan biscuit... For dessert, choose the balsamic vinegar marinated strawberries with light verbena cream, or a Nantes gateau with a touch of rum. Make sure you check out the blackboard for the day's specials!

Le Bouchon
7 rue Bossuet
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 20 08 44

https://www.le-bouchon-nantes.com

Menu: lunch from 18 EUR, dinner from 31 EUR

content.title: Forget about the 21st century at Puy du Fou!

introduction.small: Awarded the title of best theme park of the world, Puy Du Fou offers a variety of spectacular shows and adventures to enjoy with friends or family!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Forget about the 21st century at Puy du Fou!

paragraphs.text:
While staying in Nantes, treat yourself a great journey back in time at Puy du Fou's theme park! Cross time by choosing your favourite era, shows and food according to your tastes! Explore a magnificent natural reserve of more than 50 hectares hosting around 20 spectacular performances during both day and night, 4 authentic villages and their local craftsmen and more than 1,500 animals in harmony with nature.

Relive the fury of traditional circus games, enjoy knights' dazzling horse stunts, join a moving cloak-and-dagger adventure, let your imagination flow before the incredible bird ballet… each century will provide you with specific emotions. You will then be able to discover "the First Kingdom", a show that takes you back to 5th century AD, during the fall of the Roman Empire, destroyed by Attila's hordes of Barbarians. Watch the arena's various Gallo-Roman trials through the eyes of a spectator in “Sign of Triumph”, another show that will leave you breathless and asking for more. Give in to Puy du Fou's historical and wonderful epic: it is only waiting for you!

Puy du Fou
85590 Les Epesses
https://www.puydufou.com/france/en

content.title: The machines of a fabulous mechanical bestiary

introduction.small: These fantastic mechanical inventions come to life on the Ile de Nantes and are an amazing spectacle to see as a couple or as a family.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The machines of a fabulous mechanical bestiary

paragraphs.text:
The great hangars of the former shipyards located on the Ile de Nantes are the scene of construction for extraordinary machinery designed by François Delarozière and Pierre Orefice.

These gigantic mechanical structures, inspired by both Leonardo da Vinci and Jules Verne, may be visited, offering a truly original artistic and playful adventure. The big Elephant invites travellers passing along the quay to ride on its back. In the workshop you must visit the machines gallery, the bestiary of the tree of herons, and the latest addition, a sleepy spider. It embarks with four visitors in its abdomen, climbs up its web, and then moves above the public to finally rest on the ground in an amazing walk. A little further on, the Marine Worlds' carousel, a three-storey merry-go-round with 35 water creatures, animates the island between the great shipyard and the former Banana Warehouse, now home to restaurants, bars, and terraces.

Les Machines de l'Île
Parc des chantiers
Boulevard Léon Bureau
44200 Nantes

+33 (0)2 51 17 49 89

https://www.lesmachines-nantes.fr/en/

content.title: La Baule: a wild, yet civilised coastline

introduction.small: Less than an hour from Nantes, the ocean and its famous bay of La Baule are a breath of sea air coupled with a gourmet adventure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Baule: a wild, yet civilised coastline

paragraphs.text:
Nothing is easier from Nantes than reaching the chic seaside resort of La Baule.

On one of the most beautiful bays in Europe, it is a relaxing, salty paradise. For a walk, the best route is from the port of Pouliguen, having sampled a sweet “niniche” (handmade lollipop) at the Mignon confectioner's shop, down along Benoit Beach to the Hermitage, a perfect stop for a drink. A quick stroll along the Avenue General de Gaulle and its shops, with time to taste a “galette” from Barapom, and then it's the time to conquer the wild coast in the direction of Croisic. Here again there is a destination worth stopping for. Resting on the rocks, with stunning views of the Atlantic, the restaurant L'Océan is a discreet establishment in a remarkable spot, controlled with an iron hand by Mr Louis, where you can feast on fish and seafood.

The specialty, bar in a salt crust, is to die for.

content.title: Graffiti nudges the urban landscape

introduction.small: In some parts of the city, the buildings are covered with vibrant colours, a remarkable testimony to a 21st century art form.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Graffiti nudges the urban landscape

paragraphs.text:
Thanks to Pick Up Production's initiative, and notable artists, graffiti and its very contemporary subjects have gate-crashed more and more of the city's surfaces.

On the Ile de Nantes, major works, such as those of the Fabrique art lab, whose mutant cat is the star of the neighbourhood's vibrant fresco, are being perpetuated. Created by three highly creative young artists, Ador, Sémor, and Korsé, they adorn the concrete foundations of the old blockhouse, which also hosts a compressed bus in its structure, its knowing win knot to be missed day or night. The constantly renewed works of high-colour graffiti artists may also be seen randomly on the island behind the city court and along the Loire, right up to the Maillé Brézé, a former Naval squadron escort ship that has become an ephemeral museum that also features street art colours, to the delight of fans.

La Fabrique / Trempolino
6 boulevard Léon Bureau
44200 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 46 66 33

https://www.lafabrique.nantes.eu/

content.title: Le Lieu Unique: a Nantais must

introduction.small: Sixteen years ago, the architect Patrick Bouchain designed a multifaceted cultural centre in the old LU biscuit building that has become a national stage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Lieu Unique: a Nantais must

paragraphs.text:
Facing the Castle of the Dukes along the St Felix canal, close to the railway station, the building can be seen from afar thanks to its old Art Nouveau-style tower, which stands like a beacon.

It was Louis Lefèvre-Utile, founder of the famous LU biscuit brand who commissioned the architect Auguste Bluysen in 1905 to design two ornate towers to signify the prosperity of his company. Only one was saved from demolition, and it now remains, with its magical allure, emblematic of the city. The rehabilitated building is, as its name indicates, unique. At once a café, bar, and restaurant, there is also a steam room, a cultural and artistic library, and concert, conference, and exhibition venues, as well as an artist residence. It is a place to share with friends and family, a place to read, discuss, cultivate, relax, and have fun. It is also possible to observe the city from the tower, as if from a lookout post.

Le Lieu Unique
Quai Ferdinand Favre
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 12 14 34

https://www.lelieuunique.com/en/

content.title: La Civelle: a chic ‘guinguette'

introduction.small: La Civelle is an institution for regular customers who get together for a break from the city at the water's edge of the small fishing village of Trentemoult.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Civelle: a chic ‘guinguette'

paragraphs.text:
The Civelle, (named after baby eels, Loire treasures that were still being fished a few years ago, not far from here) is a place that naturally encourages relaxation. The atmosphere is good humoured, and on sunny days you can sit on the terrace. Moreover, Trentemoult, this highly colourful village, is both trendy and popular, fashionable and casual. The clientele ranges from bourgeois families and businesspeople to artists living in the neighbourhood. A multitude of different personalities converge in this place away from conventions to enjoy quality cuisine, like traditional recipes of grilled fish and meat with great taste. For instance, taste the braised lamb shanks in dried fruits with white beans from Vendée, or a swordfish steak with spicy tomato combawa sauce and coconut rice curry.

There are four dining rooms and as many atmospheres, with the upstairs having a nice view of the Loire, even if it receives fewer regulars who spontaneously meet in the warmest room, which is the bar. The brasserie style cuisine is always perfect, and the fries too!

La Civelle
21 quai Marcel Boissard
44400 Trentemoult Rezé

+33 (0)2 40 75 46 60

https://lacivelle.com

Menu: around 40 EUR

content.title: Passage Pommeraye: masterpiece of 19th-century architecture

introduction.small: If there were a spot to symbolise the wealth of the city, this would be it. Listed as a historical monument, the passage is a sculptural and architectural treasure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Passage Pommeraye: masterpiece of 19th-century architecture

paragraphs.text:
Regularly cited as one of the finest covered passages in Europe, since June 2015 the carefully restored Passage Pommeraye, (named after the man who financed its construction in 1840) is the city centre's 'classic treasure'.

Close to Rue Crébillon, renowned for the quality of its shops, the three-level passage and galleries host 26 different luxury shops, and a tearoom pastry shop. There are also leather goods and a concept store, all in a 'Parisian' spirit. Nine metres high, with oak stairs, remarkable lace wrought iron, medallions, and entry ways reminiscent of the Arc de Triomphe, it is the place to spend time strolling about and shopping, or for a tea break (at the Passagère in the Régnier gallery).

It is an incomparable pleasure that is delightfully old-fashioned.

Passage Pommeraye
44000 Nantes

https://www.passagepommeraye.fr

content.title: Trentemoult: a colourful fishing village

introduction.small: Only 10 minutes away by car or boat, Trentemoult splashes its vibrant colours on the left bank of the Loire. The atmosphere is cheerful and relaxed throughout the year.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Trentemoult: a colourful fishing village

paragraphs.text:
It is a place that the Nantais visit diligently, to stroll and to drink and eat, because the feeling of being somewhere else is instantaneous.

This ancient village of fishermen and sailors, with its small narrow streets and powerfully coloured houses, is simply irresistible. A corner of paradise, it is a cure for melancholy, shining with good humour and simplicity, which takes on the feel of a holiday resort as soon as there is a ray of sunshine. From the terraces of its bars and restaurants, the view of the city across the Loire is magical. To reach its quays without a car, you need only take the Navibus (from the Maritime station), which makes the crossing from the 'quai de la Fosse'regularly. Onsite, there are several essential addresses, notably La Civelle and the Bistrot du Port.

Don't miss the organic market on Saturday!

Trentemoult
Quai Robert Surcouf
44400 Rezé

https://www.nantes-tourisme.com/en/heritage/trentemoult

content.title: A unique artistic journey on the Loire

introduction.small: From the port of Nantes to the Saint-Nazaire Estuary, the banks of the Loire unveil 30 singular contemporary works of a vibrant character.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A unique artistic journey on the Loire

paragraphs.text:
The 'Perennial Trail' designed by Jean Blaise between Nantes and Saint-Nazaire, linked by the Loire, is an unforgettable cruise (April to October) that alternates fragile nature reserves with monumental industrial buildings, all punctuated with works by international artists along the banks of 12 communes.

The first one that catches our attention is the one located along the former banana warehouse in the port of Nantes: Daniel Buren and Patrick Bouchain's famous The Rings seem to mark the harbour entrance with their 18 circles of light. This faces the Lunar Tree, a ghostly tree perched on Sainte-Anne Hill, white by day and fluorescent by night. A little further, a house placed in the middle of the river, seems to be sinking, while another, raised above a replica of a chimney of the neighbouring thermal power plant astonishes.

If you do not want to take the boat, the route also continues on bike or on foot in the two cities of Nantes and Saint-Nazaire, with artistic interventions that highlight both cities.

+33 (0)2 40 75 75 07

https://www.estuaire.info/en/

https://www.nantes-tourisme.com/en/estuaire-trail

content.title: A life of luxury

introduction.small: Only one hour from Nantes, the quaint resort of Pornichet, with its waterfront and protected natural beaches, is a guaranteed 'get-fit' destination.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A life of luxury

paragraphs.text:
Walk down the coastal path close to the harbour, facing the ocean, to fill your lungs with salt air and the open sea. There on the sea front is the Chateau des Tourelles, a new kind of hotel led by two experts in thalassotherapy, Jean Pascal and Anne Phelippeau.

Here you will not see spa guests in bathrobes coming out of treatment rooms. Instead, you are taken in hand in an individual suite for comfort and discretion. This is the perfect stopover visit to let go for a day, or a few days, in a contemporary setting.

You can choose the care you desire, the spa, or just live in a chic and friendly atmosphere, which gives the place a special distinction. A walk to the Bonne-Source beach? A visit to the Pornichet Market and its small shops? The city offers year-round opportunities for enjoying authentic charm.

Château des Tourelles
Pointe du Bec
1 avenue Léon Dubas
44380 Pornichet

+33 (0)2 40 60 80 80

https://relaisthalasso.com/chateau-des-tourelles

content.title: Castle of the Dukes of Brittany: refinement and history

introduction.small: Discover the beautiful Breton castle fortress and its museum, which reflect the history of the city in the heart of the medieval quarter.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castle of the Dukes of Brittany: refinement and history

paragraphs.text:
This granite and limestone giant built in the 13th century by François II, the last Duke of independent Brittany, and his daughter Anne of Brittany, Queen of France, houses a residential palace with skilfully carved limestone facades and Renaissance loggias, which are essential to visit to savour the elegance of the architecture.

One side of the fortress, with its heavy defence walls, appears quite in contrast to the other, the royal residence, especially since its brilliant restoration (started in 1990 and completed in 2007) revealed a brightly white flamboyant style. The monument houses 32 rooms that tell the story of the merchant city as a western metropolis, including, of course, the Edict of Nantes, the revolution, and its dark past as France's number one slave port. Nantes' large industries like its bakeries, canneries, and shipbuilding sites are also honoured in visits that are highly documented with integrated multimedia.

A film about the great transformations of Nantes concludes the visit.

Château des Ducs de Bretagne
4 place Marc Elder
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 51 17 49 48

https://www.chateaunantes.fr

content.title: The timeless and must-see Cigale

introduction.small: Opposite the Graslin Theatre, this 1900-style brasserie, one of the world's finest, has been a meeting place for notables in the arts and entertainment worlds for more than a century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The timeless and must-see Cigale

paragraphs.text:
The Cigale, one of the city's proudest landmarks, is a great place to start your discovery of Nantes and its town centre. An Art Nouveau temple with a rich and vibrant character; it has been open since 1895.

The work of architect and ceramist Émile Libaudière, it has been listed as a heritage building since 1964, and the number of visitors who come especially for the decor are legion. All night long, there is a never-ending stream of regulars and passing visitors who come to sample traditional cuisine such as steak tartar, seasonal dishes, revisited classic recipes and seafood, while taking in the painted wood panels, the ceilings with their rich ornaments, the bevelled mirrors and sculptures. From breakfast to dinner or after a show, the obvious address in the heart of town to see and be seen in a Parisian-style brasserie ambiance is, without hesitation, the Cigale.

An oyster shucker and a tearoom with delicious pastries complete the tableau.

La Cigale
4 place Graslin
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 51 84 94 94

https://www.lacigale.com

Menu: around 35 EUR

content.title: The Radisson Blu Hotel, Nantes

introduction.small: The former city courthouse is a key downtown hotel. A heritage building brilliantly revisited by the decorator Jean Philippe Nuel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Radisson Blu Hotel, Nantes

paragraphs.text:
The Radisson Blu and its majestic glass facade standing proudly on Place Aristide Briand, has become a must in the city.

This immense neoclassical structure, with columns and allegorical statues, is more than a big four-star hotel; it is also a chic, contemporary and gourmet Nantais meeting place. The 142 rooms (from 25 to 29 sqm), including 20 suites (from 35 to 65 sqm), all cleanly and elegantly designed, are signed with a modern identity that is functional and respectful of the past. The pristine white beds contrast with the images of the city in chiaroscuro that adorn the walls. In the old concourse, which has now become the lobby, fuchsia and violet colours infuse the design with zest. L'Assise restaurant in the former audience hall, orchestrated by the chef Erwan Noblet, offers inventive, contemporary cuisine, and the morning breakfast buffet is worthy of the highest praise.

Radisson Blu
6 place Aristide Briand
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 72 00 10 00

https://www.radissonhotels.com/en-us/hotels/radisson-blu-nantes

Rooms: from 96 EUR

content.title: L'Atlantide 1874: gastronomy on the water

introduction.small: Since November 2015, starred chef Jean-Yves Guého has settled on the Sainte Anne Hill, in a new location overlooking the Loire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Atlantide 1874: gastronomy on the water

paragraphs.text:
Formerly located on the top floor of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Atlantide 1874 and its chef, whose reputation is second to none, have moved. A few hundred metres from their old address, they are now in a 19th-century mansion near the Jules Verne Museum that the chef has been eyeing for several years so that his gourmet journey might continue in a chic and contemporary atmosphere. The old abandoned house has been beautifully restored; combining stonewalls with facades of glass and wood.

Today the art of receiving, in this large and starred house run by the Guéhos, shines without ostentation on the city heights. The chef's 'travelling cuisine' combines all the subtlety of regional products with exotic flavours in a more intimate and friendly setting between an open kitchen and bright dining room. There, enjoy a marvellous roasted pollack loin, veal filet marinated in soy sauce and sesame or langoustines served smoked eel and potato mash…

The spectacle of the harbour entrance and the sunsets overlooking the river are privileged moments to experience on the terrace.

L'Atlantide 1874 – Maison Guého
5 rue de l'Hermitage
44100 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 73 23 23

https://www.atlantide1874.fr

A la carte: around 90 EUR

content.title: Pickles: alliance of the good, the beautiful, and the daring

introduction.small: Between the cathedral and the centre, this contemporary bistro combines quality products, sustainability, and audacity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pickles: alliance of the good, the beautiful, and the daring

paragraphs.text:
Dominic Quirke, a former computer programmer from the UK, has pursued his passion for cooking after training among great chefs. Here is an address with few seats, a great artist-loft style decor with industrial details, and trendy wallpaper, but more especially, a friendly atmosphere (you need to reserve, as the word is out). At Pickles, the structure is clearly defined. The menu is short, the choice of products and vegetables is uncompromising, with small carefully selected producers, fish from small boats, and precise combinations orchestrated with passion and inventiveness. The collaboration of this atypical chef with the Omnivore team, coupled with his time with Alain Senderens and Gilles Choukroun, have produced an original style and a piquant spirit of creative lightness. Cold-smoked mackerel in sauce with fennel, Breton langoustine in curry and coconut milk, preserved organic pork served with Daikon noodles, dried zucchini and young parsnip are just some of the many Asia-inspired delights, all coming with the added bonus of being fairly priced. Jean Baptiste Truchard, the sommelier who earned his badge at the Crillon in Paris, proposes a selection of affordable wines. This is the best value in town.

Pickles
2 rue du Marais
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 51 84 11 89

https://www.pickles-restaurant.com

Menu: around 22 EUR

content.title: Okko Hotel: Urban design

introduction.small: A unique concept for comfort and conviviality, this four-star experience is managed completely online. The result? No wasted time at check in or check out, and an intimate ‘all-inclusive' welcome.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Okko Hotel: Urban design

paragraphs.text:
The Okko spirit is a new idea of affordable luxury, coupled with genuine friendliness.

The hotel, located close to the Castle of the Dukes of Brittany, is resolutely modern, and organised so that your stay will be pleasant and especially easy-going. Each of the 80 rooms has a coffee maker, available movies, and free Wi-Fi. The club area is accessible 24/7 with two fridges full of cold drinks, and for sudden cravings at any hour, biscuits, cheese, and mini quiches are offered. For working, there are two computers and a printer, and if you like the design furniture, it can be purchased on the hotel's e-shop. It's simple and tasteful, and you are welcomed directly by Annette Thomas and her team at any moment during the day or night, without having to register at a front desk.

Everything is easy, unpretentious, and accessible, including the sauna and fitness area. It's a new way of hotel living.

Okko Hotel
15 rue de Strasbourg
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 52 20 00 70

https://www.okkohotels.com/en/page/nantes/.3097.html

Rooms: from 84 EUR

content.title: Maison Guého: wide-angle nights on the Loire

introduction.small: Four contemporary guest rooms in a completely restored mansion overlooking the Loire offer the opportunity for lovely dreams after a gourmet dinner.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maison Guého: wide-angle nights on the Loire

paragraphs.text:
Since November 2015, the well-known Nantais chef, Jean Yves Guého has taken over a house he has dreamed of for years on the Sainte-Anne hill. It is a large house that has been done over by combining the old with a bright contemporary design that, while being respectful of the past, gives the old mansion a chic new life.

Here, the chef and his wife combine gourmet pleasures with relaxation, with a view of the river and the lovely little fishing village. The feeling of being on a boat is palpable. The rooms are small but functional and nicely appointed. It is a formula that allows one to be carried away by a real experience in the art of entertaining.

The ideal being to have a drink and enjoy the sunset on the terrace, feast on the chef's excellent recipes, then relax by spending the night in this new starred gastronomic temple.

Maison Guého
5 rue de l'Hermitage
44100 Nantes

+33 (0)2 40 73 23 23

https://www.atlantide1874.fr/

Rooms: from 130 EUR

content.title: The Sōzō Hotel: religious about design

introduction.small: Sōzō (which means "imagination" in Japanese) is a distinctive hotel in a 19th-century chapel that Benoit Boiteau has tastefully and passionately designed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Sōzō Hotel: religious about design

paragraphs.text:
In a quiet area close to the station and the botanical gardens, ten minutes from the town centre, the Sōzō Hotel has an exceptional character that pits religious architecture against sleek design. Bright-coloured furnishings by Pierre Paulin in the lobby, lighting by Ingo Maurer, and a collection of guitars and a grand piano set the tone of the place, which is decidedly different. There is no doubt upon entry that this address is for design lovers, artists of all kinds, and those who love singularity. The 23 rooms and one suite are part of a stained-glass world, with vaulted archways and columns associated with elegant decor. Nothing is left to chance in terms of comfort, with air conditioning, a steam room and sauna, a sensorial shower, an ice room, and very comfortable bedding. The newest hotel suite (55 sqm), in the image of the hotel, is a discreet and intimate sanctuary of comfort and technology with luxurious design.

Sōzō Hotel
16 rue Frédéric Cailliaud
44000 Nantes

+33 (0)2 51 82 40 00

https://www.sozohotel.fr/en/

Rooms: from 103 EUR

content.title: Unusual nights with Jules Verne

introduction.small: For those who love originality, this address is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Unusual nights with Jules Verne

paragraphs.text:
Surprising and unusual are the two characteristics of the apartments and the XL room located opposite the big elephant from the Ile de Nantes.

In one of the most splendid buildings in the city on the Quai de la Fosse, three accommodations tracing the life of famous writer Jules Verne offer a unique experience in terms of decor. 'From the Earth to the Moon', 'Extraordinary Journeys' and 'Night' were designed by the decorator Yann Falquero, which evoke here the fantastic imagination of the writer. The Jules Verne's 'souplex, bedroom (a duplex with a ground floor and a basement) is a real plunge into history. The kitchen is in a rocket, and children sleep above in a spaceship. Objects and books surround you, making it feel like home.

The concept is somewhere between a hotel room and a guesthouse, and a great opportunity for shared memories, especially since the three apartments can be joined into a single space.

Plateau Jules Verne
86 quai de la Fosse
44100 Nantes

+33 (0)6 38 44 49 98

https://surprenantes.com/en/nantes/le-plateau-jules-verne

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: A dazzling address in the heart of the Briere marshes

introduction.small: Just 45 minutes from Nantes, chef Éric Guérin offers both an exquisite table and an atypical hotel of great comfort in a peaceful natural reserve.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A dazzling address in the heart of the Briere marshes

paragraphs.text:
Take the time to enjoy an extraordinary experience between Nantes and La Baule, away from the bustle, far from the fashionable standards, in a delightful, unclassifiable place, which is the creative culmination of a chef's passion. Nestled in the green countryside, the house seems to deliver a message of peace and wellness, of real character that plays naturally with humour and poetry. If the weather is good you can enjoy an aperitif in the garden, but be vigilant to ensure that the crowned cranes do not come to peck at your appetisers. This first experience in the extraordinary garden keeping company with restaurant's resident wild birds is alone an exceptional moment. But it is through his cuisine that Éric expresses his emotions with singular creativity. He produces "dishes that heckle" transcribing the world and its news in assemblies of original flavours: ray fish cheeks in three wild rices, apricot pickles and flower butter, silurid fish from the Loire river in Guérande sea salt, melon ceviche with regional sprouts and lemon, or even pork wrapped in lettuce and served with honeyed potato blinis. Dining there is an experience to renew without moderation.

La Mare aux Oiseaux
223 rue du Chef de l'Île
44720 Saint-Joachim

+33 (0)2 40 88 53 01

https://www.mareauxoiseaux.fr/?lang=en

Menu: around 55 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Nantes
content.introduction: Nantes enjoys a temperate, oceanic climate, strongly influenced by the Loire estuary and the absence of hilly or mountainous terrain. Winters (from December to March) are mild and rainy. At least one heat wave lasting a few days is often experienced in the summer (from June to September). There is frequent, but not heavy, rainfall over the rest of the year. Long periods of strong winds may occur throughout the year, although they are not especially violent.

airports.title: Nantes-Atlantique Airport
airports.description:
The Nantes-Atlantique Airport is located just outside the city's ring road, at the Porte de Grand Lieu, 10 minutes from the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Nantes and back:
  • By car
    • Access via the ring road by exiting through Porte Grand-Lieu or Bourguenais (rue de l'Aviation).
    • There are several parking facilities:
      • Long-term parking (more than 5 days) at P0 Ouest, P0 Est, P0 Nord and P1 Sud.
      • Short-term parking (less than 5 days) at P2, P2 Est, P3 Nord, P3 Ouest.
    • Several car rental companies have counters in a separate building, just outside the terminal.
  • By shuttle bus
    • La Navette Aéroport is a shuttle bus service connecting the airport with central Nantes, with departures every 20 minutes from 5:30 a.m. to 11:15 p.m. Monday to Saturday and every 30 minutes from 6:20 a.m. to 11:15 p.m. on Sunday (EUR 9 each way).
  • By bus
    • Bus line 98 station is located about 100 metres from the airport and connects it with the city centre.
  • By taxi
    • A taxi rank is located just outside the terminal opposite Hall 3. The fare to the city centre is about EUR 30 to EUR 35.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, parking valet and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)2 40 84 80 00
  • Website: https://www.nantes.aeroport.fr/en/homepage
  • Customers with a Paris connexion and an Air France flight number (either from Roissy or Orly) must visit the TGV AIR desk at the Nantes train station 24 hours to 20 minutes before departure: train tickets will be issued to them upon presentation of a valid airplane ticket. For all necessary information, please visit https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/resainfovol/avion_train/reservation_avion_train_tgvair_airfrance.htm
  • The Nantes train station is located at 27 boulevard de Stalingrad, 44041 Nantes. It is open every day from 4:20 a.m. to 11:15 p.m.:
    • Access via public transportation: tramway (line 1), intercity buses (lines 6, 7, 11, 12 and 13) and city buses (lines C2, C3 and C5).
    • Access via private transportation: drop off area, self-service car sharing, rental car companies, taxis, parking lots, bike rentals.
  • For all necessary information about the TGV AIR desk, please visit https://www.garesetconnexions.sncf/fr/gare/frnte/nantes/services/guichets-ventes-gare-nord

Although the historic centre of Nantes can still be accessed by car, traffic is limited to residents and deliveries.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Nantes
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Nantes each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April : Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1 : Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: Around May 19: Fête de la Bretagne (Gouel Breizh) (local)
events.description: Since 1997, the Fête de la Bretagne attracts 400,000 people each year, with more than 200 different events (concerts, exhibitions, shows, treks, picnics, conferences and strolls).

events.title: June 21 : Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets, parks and at various venues across Nantes.

events.title: July 14 : Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Nantes, a huge fireworks display is set off from the island in the centre of the city and is best viewed from the Quai de la Fosse or the Pont Anne de Bretagne. There are also many dance parties open to everyone held at various venues throughout the city.

events.title: August 15 : Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Nantes, is marked by the faithful with religious processions and ceremonies through the streets.

events.title: Third weekend in September : European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Nantes, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

Tipping
In Nantes like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
